newsitem.title: UK: IRA's bomb scares off N.Ireland conference.
newsitem.headline: IRA's bomb scares off N.Ireland conference.

text.p: IRA violence has forced the cancellation of a high-profile broadcasters' conference planned in Belfast next July, British officials said on Tuesday.

Organisers of the European Broadcasting Union's three-day gathering decided this month to switch it to Edinburgh, Scotland, after the Irish Republican Army's first attack in Northern Ireland for more than two years. the sources said.
"We are naturally very disappointed that they have based their decision on one incident," said a spokesman for Britain's Northern Ireland Office.
"We are still convinced that if they had held their conference in Northern Ireland they would have had a trouble-free, productive and pleasant time."
There was no initial comment from the Geneva-based organisation.
The IRA's double car bomb attack at British military headquarters in Lisburn, 10 miles (15 km) south of Belfast killed a soldier and injured 30 other people.
It dashed slim hopes of a ceasefire by the banned guerrillas and raised fears that the IRA's pro-British Loyalist rivals will abandon their own two-year truce.
The sources said the EBU considered changing the date of the conference after sectarian clashes in mid-July at the height of the volatile annual "marching season" by Protestants.
It decided to pull out of the Belfast arrangements completely after the IRA bombing on October 7.
The loss of the conference will strike a blow to the province's tourist industry, which had been recovering thanks to two years of peace.
